standard.name: NIS-2 Directive (EU) 2022/2555
standard.description: Directive on measures for a high common level of cybersecurity across the Union. Replaces the NIS Directive with expanded scope and stricter requirements for essential and important entities.

controls.name: Risk Analysis and Information System Security Policies
controls.description: Policies for risk analysis and information system security

article.section_name: Risk Analysis and Information System Security Policies
article.full_text: Member States shall ensure that essential and important entities take appropriate and proportionate technical, operational and organisational measures to manage the risks posed to the security of network and information systems which those entities use for their operations or for the provision of their services, and to prevent or minimise the impact of incidents on recipients of their services and on other services. Taking into account the state of the art and, where applicable, the relevant European and international standards, as well as the cost of implementation, those measures shall ensure a level of security of network and information systems appropriate to the risks posed. Entities shall take measures including policies on risk analysis and information system security.
article.guidance: Organizations must establish comprehensive policies covering risk assessment methodologies, risk appetite statements, and information system security requirements. Risk analysis should be performed regularly and updated when significant changes occur. The policy framework should address both technical and business risks, including supply chain risks. ISO 27005 and NIST frameworks provide guidance on risk management approaches.
article.external_references: Article 21(2)(a), ISO 27001, ISO 27005, NIST Cybersecurity Framework

controls.name: Incident Handling
controls.description: Incident handling procedures and processes

article.full_text: Entities shall take measures including incident handling. Incident handling procedures must address detection, response, recovery and lessons learned. Significant incidents must be reported to the competent authority or CSIRT without undue delay.
article.guidance: Implement a formal incident response capability with defined roles, procedures, and communication channels. Establish incident classification criteria aligned with NIS-2 notification requirements. Maintain incident response playbooks for common scenarios. Conduct regular tabletop exercises and simulations. Ensure 24/7 incident response capability or access to external support. Document all incidents and conduct post-incident reviews.
article.external_references: Article 21(2)(b), Article 23 (Reporting obligations), ISO 27035, NIST SP 800-61

controls.name: Business Continuity and Crisis Management
controls.description: Business continuity, backup management and disaster recovery, and crisis management

article.full_text: Entities shall take measures including business continuity, such as backup management and disaster recovery, and crisis management. Business continuity plans must be tested regularly and updated to reflect changing risks and business requirements.
article.guidance: Develop and maintain business continuity plans (BCP) and disaster recovery plans (DRP) covering all critical systems and services. Define recovery time objectives (RTO) and recovery point objectives (RPO) for each critical service. Implement automated backup solutions with off-site storage and encryption. Test restoration procedures regularly. Establish crisis management teams and communication protocols. Consider dependencies on third-party services and suppliers in continuity planning.
article.external_references: Article 21(2)(c), ISO 22301, ISO 27031

controls.name: Supply Chain Security
controls.description: Supply chain security, including security-related aspects of relationships with suppliers

article.full_text: Entities shall take measures including supply chain security, including security-related aspects concerning the relationships between each entity and its direct suppliers or service providers. This includes assessing the overall quality of products and cybersecurity practices of suppliers, with particular attention to hardware and software products that are critical for security.
article.guidance: Implement a supplier security assessment program covering cybersecurity capabilities, incident response, and security practices. Include security requirements in supplier contracts with audit rights. Maintain an inventory of critical suppliers and service providers. Assess supply chain risks including concentration risk and geographic dependencies. Monitor supplier security posture through certifications, audits, and continuous assessment. Address vulnerabilities in the software supply chain including open source components.
article.external_references: Article 21(2)(d), ISO 28000, NIST SP 800-161, C5ISCP

controls.name: Security in Network and Information Systems Acquisition, Development and Maintenance
controls.description: Security in acquisition, development and maintenance of network and information systems

article.section_name: Security in Network and Information Systems Acquisition, Development and Maintenance
article.full_text: Entities shall take measures including security in network and information systems acquisition, development and maintenance, including vulnerability handling and disclosure. This includes implementing security by design principles and ensuring security is integrated throughout the system development lifecycle.
article.guidance: Adopt secure development lifecycle (SDL) practices including threat modeling, secure coding standards, and security testing. Implement security requirements in procurement processes for hardware, software, and services. Establish vulnerability management program including scanning, assessment, and patching. Participate in coordinated vulnerability disclosure programs. Use security testing tools including SAST, DAST, and dependency scanning. Maintain secure development environments separate from production.
article.external_references: Article 21(2)(e), ISO 27034, OWASP SAMM, NIST SP 800-218

controls.name: Policies and Procedures for Assessing the Effectiveness of Cybersecurity Measures
controls.description: Policies and procedures to assess the effectiveness of cybersecurity risk management measures

article.section_name: Policies and Procedures for Assessing Effectiveness
article.full_text: Entities shall take measures including policies and procedures to assess the effectiveness of cybersecurity risk-management measures. Regular testing, auditing and review of the effectiveness of measures should be conducted.
article.guidance: Establish a security metrics and measurement program to assess control effectiveness. Conduct regular security assessments including vulnerability assessments, penetration testing, and security audits. Perform security control testing aligned with frameworks like NIST SP 800-53A. Review and update security measures based on assessment findings. Track key risk indicators (KRIs) and key performance indicators (KPIs). Engage independent third parties for objective assessments. Document all findings and remediation activities.
article.external_references: Article 21(2)(f), ISO 27004, NIST SP 800-53A

controls.name: Basic Cyber Hygiene Practices and Cybersecurity Training
controls.description: Basic cyber hygiene practices and cybersecurity training

article.section_name: Basic Cyber Hygiene Practices and Training
article.full_text: Entities shall take measures including basic cyber hygiene practices and cybersecurity training. This includes training for staff with access to critical systems and regular awareness programs for all personnel.
article.guidance: Implement comprehensive security awareness program covering phishing, social engineering, password security, and incident reporting. Provide role-based training for personnel with privileged access or security responsibilities. Conduct regular phishing simulations and track metrics. Ensure management receives cybersecurity briefings. Include security responsibilities in job descriptions and performance evaluations. Maintain training records and require periodic refresher training. Address remote work security practices.
article.external_references: Article 21(2)(g), NIST SP 800-50, ENISA Cybersecurity Training

controls.name: Cryptography and Encryption
controls.description: Policies and procedures regarding the use of cryptography and encryption

article.full_text: Entities shall take measures including policies and procedures regarding the use of cryptography and, where appropriate, encryption. Cryptographic controls should be used to protect the confidentiality, authenticity and integrity of data.
article.guidance: Develop cryptography policy covering algorithm selection, key management, and encryption use cases. Implement encryption for data at rest and in transit. Use strong, standardized cryptographic algorithms (AES-256, RSA-2048+, TLS 1.3+). Establish key management procedures including generation, distribution, storage, rotation, and destruction. Consider post-quantum cryptography for long-term data protection. Use hardware security modules (HSMs) for key protection where appropriate. Maintain cryptographic inventories.
article.external_references: Article 21(2)(h), ISO 27002:2022 Section 8.24, NIST SP 800-175B, eIDAS Regulation

controls.name: Human Resources Security
controls.description: Human resources security, access control policies and asset management

article.full_text: Entities shall take measures including human resources security, access control policies and asset management. This includes background verification, employment contracts with security clauses, and access management procedures.
article.guidance: Implement pre-employment screening appropriate to the role sensitivity and legal requirements. Include confidentiality and security clauses in employment contracts. Define clear roles and responsibilities for security. Implement joiner-mover-leaver processes ensuring timely access provisioning and revocation. Apply principle of least privilege. Conduct regular access reviews. Maintain asset inventory and assignment records. Address insider threat risks through monitoring and controls. Implement secure offboarding procedures.
article.external_references: Article 21(2)(i), ISO 27001 A.6 (People Controls), GDPR considerations

controls.name: Multi-Factor Authentication and Secure Voice, Video and Text Communications
controls.description: Use of multi-factor authentication, continuous authentication solutions and secured communication systems

article.full_text: Entities shall take measures including the use of multi-factor authentication or continuous authentication solutions, secured voice, video and text communications and secured emergency communication systems within the entity, where appropriate. Multi-factor authentication shall be implemented for remote access, privileged access, and access to critical systems.
article.guidance: Deploy multi-factor authentication (MFA) for all remote access, privileged accounts, and access to critical systems. Prefer phishing-resistant MFA (FIDO2, smart cards, biometrics) over SMS-based codes. Implement risk-based authentication adjusting requirements based on context. Use end-to-end encrypted communication tools for sensitive discussions. Establish secure emergency communication channels independent of primary systems. Consider zero trust architecture principles. Implement continuous authentication for high-risk scenarios.
article.external_references: Article 21(2)(j), NIST SP 800-63B, FIDO Alliance standards, eIDAS

controls.name: Management Body Oversight and Accountability
controls.description: Management body must approve cybersecurity measures, oversee implementation, and be trained

article.full_text: The management body of the entity shall be required to approve the cybersecurity risk-management measures taken by that entity to comply with paragraph 2, oversee their implementation and be trained to sufficiently understand and assess the cybersecurity risks and management practices. Member States shall ensure that members of the management body who are found to be in breach of obligations may be held personally liable.
article.guidance: Board and senior management must approve cybersecurity strategy and policies. Establish regular reporting to management on cybersecurity posture, incidents, and risks. Provide cybersecurity training to board members and executives. Include cybersecurity in board meeting agendas. Define clear accountability for cybersecurity at executive level (CISO or equivalent). Document management decisions and approvals. Ensure management understands potential personal liability. Establish cybersecurity governance committee if appropriate.
article.external_references: Article 21(3), ENISA Management Body Guidelines, ISO 27014

controls.name: Significant Incident Notification - Early Warning
controls.description: Early warning notification within 24 hours of becoming aware of significant incident

article.full_text: Entities shall notify, without undue delay and in any event within 24 hours of becoming aware of significant incidents, the CSIRT or, where applicable, the competent authority of any significant incident having an impact on the provision of their services. That notification shall enable the CSIRT or the competent authority to determine whether the significant incident has a cross-border impact. That notification, containing the information set out in paragraph 5, may be provided in phases, where necessary.
article.guidance: Establish incident classification criteria to determine significance aligned with Annex I thresholds (service disruption, data breach impact, economic impact, affected users). Implement 24/7 incident detection and notification capability. Maintain contact details for relevant CSIRT and competent authorities. Prepare notification templates with required information. Document incident timeline starting from awareness. Consider automation for rapid notification. Designate responsible persons for notification decisions. Early warning can be brief with limited initial information.
article.external_references: Article 23(1), Annex I (Criteria for significant incidents), ENISA Incident Notification Guidelines

controls.name: Significant Incident Notification - Incident Report
controls.description: Incident notification within 72 hours with initial assessment

article.full_text: Where requested by the CSIRT or the competent authority pursuant to paragraph 2, entities shall submit, without undue delay and in any event within 72 hours of becoming aware of the significant incident, an incident notification updating the information provided pursuant to paragraph 1 and an initial assessment of the significant incident, including its severity and impact, as well as, where available, indicators of compromise. That notification may be provided in phases, where necessary.
article.guidance: Within 72 hours, provide detailed incident notification including impact assessment, affected systems and services, number of affected users, severity classification, and available indicators of compromise (IoCs). Include information about ongoing response activities and estimated recovery time. Share technical details that may help other entities. Document information sources and assessment methodology. Update notification as new information becomes available. Coordinate with internal stakeholders for accurate impact assessment.
article.external_references: Article 23(4), Implementing Regulation on incident notification

controls.name: Significant Incident Notification - Final Report
controls.description: Final report within one month including detailed analysis and response

article.full_text: Upon request of the CSIRT or the competent authority, entities shall submit a final report not later than one month after the notification pursuant to paragraph 4. For significant incidents with a significant or substantial impact on service continuity, the final report shall include: a detailed description of the incident including its severity and impact; the type of threat or root cause that likely triggered the incident; the applied and ongoing mitigation measures; where applicable, the cross-border impact of the incident.
article.guidance: Conduct thorough post-incident analysis including root cause, attack timeline, and impact quantification. Document lessons learned and preventive measures. Include technical details about threat actors, attack vectors, and indicators of compromise. Describe response effectiveness and areas for improvement. Detail implemented remediation measures and future prevention steps. Calculate financial and operational impact. Assess cross-border implications. Coordinate final report with legal and communications teams as needed.
article.external_references: Article 23(6), ISO 27035-3 (Post-incident activities)

controls.name: Voluntary Incident Reporting
controls.description: Option to report incidents that don't meet significance threshold

article.full_text: Without prejudice to the notification requirements laid down in this Article, entities may, on a voluntary basis, report to the CSIRT or the competent authority referred to in paragraph 1 incidents that do not qualify as significant.
article.guidance: Consider voluntary reporting for near-miss incidents, attempted attacks, and security events that provide value to the community. Voluntary reporting helps build relationships with CSIRTs and contributes to threat intelligence sharing. Use voluntary reporting as practice for mandatory reporting procedures. Document rationale for not classifying incidents as significant. Participate in information sharing communities and platforms. Balance transparency with confidentiality concerns.
article.external_references: Article 23(7), Information sharing frameworks, ENISA guidelines

controls.name: Incident Reporting to Recipients
controls.description: Obligation to inform recipients of services affected by significant incidents

article.full_text: Without prejudice to personal data protection rules, entities shall inform the recipients of their services of significant incidents, where applicable, and of measures or remedies that the recipients may take in response to those significant incidents. Notification shall be provided without undue delay and should include information about the incident, its likely consequences, and steps recipients can take to mitigate adverse effects.
article.guidance: Develop incident communication templates for different stakeholder groups (customers, users, partners). Balance transparency with security considerations - avoid revealing information that could aid attackers. Provide actionable guidance to recipients (password changes, monitoring recommendations). Coordinate with communications and legal teams. Consider GDPR requirements if personal data is involved. Establish channels for stakeholder questions. Document all external communications. Time communications appropriately to allow defensive measures.
article.external_references: Article 23(8), GDPR Article 33 (breach notification), Crisis communication best practices

controls.name: Supervisory Measures and Enforcement
controls.description: Competent authorities may conduct on-site inspections, audits, and security scans

article.full_text: Competent authorities shall have the powers to conduct or order on-site inspections and off-site supervision of essential and important entities, including audits. They may order security scans and vulnerability assessments, require evidence of implementation of cybersecurity policies, and request access to data necessary to assess compliance with the directive. Authorities may issue binding instructions and require entities to implement specific security measures.
article.guidance: Prepare for regulatory inspections by maintaining comprehensive documentation of all security measures and policies. Implement audit logging to demonstrate compliance. Designate liaison persons for regulatory interactions. Conduct self-assessments using regulatory expectations. Respond promptly to information requests. Consider conducting third-party audits to validate compliance. Maintain evidence of management oversight and decision-making. Document risk assessments and mitigation decisions. Be prepared to demonstrate testing and effectiveness of controls.
article.external_references: Article 32, National implementation guidelines, Sector-specific requirements

controls.name: Jurisdiction and Penalties
controls.description: Member states must establish penalties including administrative fines

article.full_text: Member States shall lay down the rules on penalties applicable to infringements of national provisions adopted pursuant to this Directive and shall take all measures necessary to ensure that they are implemented. The penalties provided for must be effective, proportionate and dissuasive. For essential entities, maximum administrative fines shall be at least EUR 10,000,000 or at least 2% of total worldwide annual turnover. For important entities, maximum fines shall be at least EUR 7,000,000 or at least 1.4% of total worldwide annual turnover.
article.guidance: Understand classification as essential or important entity and corresponding penalty exposure. Document compliance efforts and good faith attempts to meet requirements. Implement compliance monitoring program with regular reviews. Allocate sufficient budget and resources for cybersecurity. Consider cyber insurance coverage for incident response and potential fines. Maintain incident response retainer with legal counsel. Document all regulatory interactions. Respond promptly and comprehensively to competent authority requests. Implement remediation recommendations quickly.
article.external_references: Article 33, National penalty frameworks, Sector regulations

controls.name: Provision of Information
controls.description: Voluntary information sharing with single points of contact and CSIRTs

article.full_text: Entities may provide relevant information to the competent authorities, the single points of contact and the CSIRTs on a voluntary basis or upon request. Such information may include cyber threats, near-misses, and indicators of compromise. Competent authorities and CSIRTs shall handle provided information in accordance with confidentiality requirements.
article.guidance: Participate in threat intelligence sharing platforms and communities. Share indicators of compromise (IoCs), tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) from incidents. Contribute to sector-specific information sharing organizations. Balance sharing with confidentiality and competitive concerns. Use automated threat intelligence feeds. Participate in trusted communities (ISACs, CERTs). Provide feedback on shared intelligence. Establish processes for sanitizing and sharing threat information. Consider anonymized incident reporting.
article.external_references: Article 34, ENISA threat intelligence frameworks, MISP, STIX/TAXII

controls.name: Criteria for Significant Incidents - Operational Impact
controls.description: Assessment criteria based on service disruption duration and affected users

article.full_text: An incident shall be considered significant if it has caused or is capable of causing severe operational disruption of the services or financial loss for the entity concerned; or has affected or is capable of affecting other natural or legal persons by causing considerable material or non-material damage. Thresholds include: service unavailability exceeding specific duration thresholds depending on sector; affecting significant number or percentage of users; or causing significant economic impact.
article.guidance: Define service-specific thresholds aligned with Annex I criteria. Consider both actual and potential impact when classifying incidents. Document decision-making process for incident classification. Err on the side of caution - when in doubt, report. Track metrics like RTO, user count, and financial impact for rapid classification. Establish pre-defined scenarios that constitute significant incidents. Consider cascading effects on dependent services. Account for reputational and regulatory impact beyond immediate operational effects.
article.external_references: Annex I, Implementing acts on incident classification, Sector-specific thresholds

controls.name: Criteria for Significant Incidents - Affected Users
controls.description: Number and type of users affected by the incident

article.full_text: Criteria for determining significance include the number of users affected by the disruption of the service, in particular if users rely on the service for critical activities or for essential services. The assessment should consider the type of users (consumers, businesses, public administrations) and dependencies on the service.
article.guidance: Maintain accurate user counts and categorization for rapid impact assessment. Define user criticality levels based on service dependency. Consider indirect impacts through service dependencies and supply chains. Document critical user groups (hospitals, emergency services, etc.). Implement monitoring to detect user impact quickly. Establish communication channels with major users for impact assessment. Consider geographical distribution of affected users for cross-border assessment.
article.external_references: Annex I(2), Service dependency mapping

controls.name: Criteria for Significant Incidents - Geographic Spread
controls.description: Geographic scope and cross-border impact of incidents

article.full_text: The geographic spread of the area affected by the incident, particularly if the incident affects more than one Member State, shall be considered in determining significance. Cross-border impacts require coordination between national authorities.
article.guidance: Map service coverage across Member States. Establish procedures for notifying multiple competent authorities when incidents affect multiple countries. Coordinate with EU-CyCLONe for cross-border incidents. Identify potential cross-border dependencies in service architecture. Maintain contact details for relevant CSIRTs in all affected Member States. Consider language requirements for international notifications. Document geographic service boundaries clearly.
article.external_references: Annex I(3), EU-CyCLONe procedures, Cross-border cooperation frameworks
